lesson.title: HTTP Networking
lesson.summary: Learn how to connect to the internet in your Android code.

atoms.title: Permissions in Android
atoms.instructor_notes: Dangerous permissions Normal permissions Other resources: Reference documentation for all permissions Emoji provided by http://emojione.com

instruction.text: Now you’ll have a chance to practice adding a permission to an existing Android app. 1. Download the Soonami app project located at this Github link. Click on the “Clone or download” button and then select “Download zip”. 2. Import the project into Android Studio. Have a look around the project, and see what code you recognize. 3. When you build the app and run it on your device, the app should crash with the Security Exception we saw in the previous video. Check the log messages in Android Studio to find the error stacktrace. ### Your Turn Fix the app by adding the internet permission. Feel free to search online for resources related to this task. When you’re done, the app should look like this.

atoms.title: The HyperText Transfer Protocol (HTTP)
atoms.instructor_notes: Link to HTTP / REST Tutorial Emoji provided by http://emojione.com

atoms.title: Read Existing Code
atoms.text:
## Read through the Soonami App code

Take a moment to become familiar with the [Soonami code](https://github.com/udacity/ud843_Soonami) related to the HTTP request and response. This is very challenging code to understand, so it’s normal for you to feel overwhelmed. 

Try to go through line-by-line in the MainActivity.java code, even if you don’t know what it means. Notice what variables are created and what methods are called. Notice how the return values of certain methods are used in subsequent lines of code. We don’t expect you to understand everything yet, but prepare to answer a series of questions about the code.

## Share advice on how to read code?

If you have any advice for other students on how to approach reading existing code that you didn’t write, we’d appreciate if you could leave your suggestions in this discussion forum thread. Thank you!

**Note:** For question #2, modify the Soonami app to use this alternative USGS query URL. **Additional Resources:** - Java tutorial: Working with URLs - Spotify API endpoints Emoji provided by http://emojione.com

question.prompt: For the Soonami App, name the variable that holds the HTTP request URL
For the Soonami App, modify the URL value to use different USGS URL (see link below). Then run the app on your device. Name the earthquake that now appears in the app.

atoms.title: URL Object
atoms.instructor_notes: Documentation for URL class Article on Working with URLs

atoms.instructor_notes: This is an outdated system architecture diagram, but you can check it out if it helps you understand the layers better. There’s another diagram here, which shows more technical details about the lower layers of the device architecture.

atoms.instructor_notes: HTTP request types HTTP methods: GET vs POST Emoji provided by http://emojione.com

atoms.instructor_notes: URLConnection connect() method Emoji provided by http://emojione.com

atoms.title: HTTP Response Codes
atoms.instructor_notes: HTTP Status Codes Valid URL: http://earthquake.usgs.gov/fdsnws/event/1/query?format=geojson&starttime=2014-01-01&endtime=2014-01-02 Invalid URL: http://earthquake.usgs.gov/fdsnws/event/1/query?format=geojson&starttime=2014-01-01&endtime=2014-01-02asdfasdf Emoji provided by http://emojione.com

concepts.title: Check HTTP Response Code in Soonami App

atoms.title: Check HTTP Response Code in Soonami App
atoms.instructor_notes: Hint: See HttpUrlConnection getResponseCode() method To make the code more robust, handle the empty or null case in the networking code. For example, if the url is null, we shouldn’t try to make the HTTP request. Or if the JSON response is null or empty string, we shouldn’t try to continue with parsing it.

instruction.text:
In the last quiz, you confirmed that a successful request returns a 200 response code. 

Let’s build that logic into our app. We should check that we do get at 200 response code, before we continue with trying to parse the JSON response. 

If we received an error response code, just return an empty string for the JSON response. it wouldn’t make sense to try to extract the feature array from the response because there would be no earthquake information in the response!

Also double check the code to make sure you handle empty or null cases in the networking code in a reasonable manner. See the note below the quiz for more details. For example, if the url is null, we shouldn’t try to make the HTTP request. Or if the JSON response is null or empty string, we shouldn’t try to continue with parsing it.

question.title: Check HTTP Response Code in Soonami App

atoms.title: Reading From an Input Stream
atoms.instructor_notes: Converting the InputStream to a String

atoms.title: Exceptions
atoms.instructor_notes: If you're interested, check out this tutorial on exceptions! You may also find information on Specifying Exceptions Thrown by a Method or Checked and unchecked exceptions useful

instruction.text:
Now it’s your turn to look through the other examples of exceptions being caught in the Soonami app. 

What exception is being caught in the makeHttpRequest method? And in the extractFeatureFromJson method?

atoms.title: Log errors
atoms.instructor_notes: **Hint:** Use the Log.e method call **Solution Code**

atoms.title: Congratulations
atoms.instructor_notes: One of the best ways to really learn a topic is to teach someone else. Use these HTTP Request and Response Diagrams to teach someone else what you've just learned!
